questions.text: Optic nerve glioma is seen in:(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NF-1 (Neurofibromatosis Type 1)

 

NF-1 is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple noncancerous (benign) tumors of nerves and skin (neurofibromas) and areas of abnormal skin coloration. Among other complications, individuals with NF-1 may develop optic nerve gliomas, which are benign brain tumors that involve the optic nerves. These tumors typically appear in childhood and can cause vision problems.

 

Also seen in NF-1 are Lisch Nodules

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B Tuberous Sclerosis: Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder that causes noncancerous tumors to form in many different organs, primarily in the brain, eyes, heart, kidney, skin, and lungs. While it is associated with a variety of brain tumors, optic nerve gliomas are not a characteristic feature of tuberous sclerosis.

 

Option C Sturge-Weber syndrome: Sturge-Weber syndrome is a rare disorder present at birth, characterized by a port-wine stain birthmark on the face and neurological abnormalities. There is the development of abnormal blood vessels on the brain's surface, but optic nerve gliomas are not typically associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

Option D Von Hippel-Lindau disease: Von Hippel-Lindau disease is a hereditary condition associated with tumors arising in multiple organs. Hemangioblastomas of the brain, spine, and retina, pheochromocytomas of the adrenal gland, and renal cell carcinomas are common. However, optic nerve gliomas are not commonly seen in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic nerve glioma, is a type of brain tumor that affects the optic nerve, is commonly associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF-1) and not typically seen in Tuberous Sclerosis, Sturge-Weber syndrome, or Von Hippel-Lindau disease.

choices.text: Metastasis to breast from another primary site

questions.text: Identify the image. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibroadenoma

 

On ultrasound, fibroadenomas typically appear as well-defined, homogeneous, hypoechoic (dark) masses with smooth margins. They may sometimes exhibit a 'halo' sign, which is a thin, echogenic rim surrounding the lesion. The mass in the image shows these characteristic features, making fibroadenoma a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast Cyst: Cysts are fluid-filled sacs within the breast. On ultrasound, they appear as anechoic (completely black) round or oval structures with well-defined edges and posterior acoustic enhancement (increased brightness behind the cyst due to lack of absorption of ultrasound waves by the fluid). The lesion in the image does not show these typical features of a cyst.

 

Option C. Breast Carcinoma: Breast cancers can appear in various forms on ultrasound, but they typically present as irregular, microlobulated, or spiculated masses with heterogenous echotexture and may show shadowing due to their density. The margins are often ill-defined, which is not consistent with the well-defined borders seen in the image.

 

Option D. Metastasis to Breast from Another Primary Site: Metastases to the breast are rare and usually present as multiple round masses that can mimic benign lesions. However, they are not common and typically have a background of known primary malignancy elsewhere, which isn't indicated here.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Fibroadenoma appearance on USG is as a ‘Halo’ sign.

questions.text: A woman presents with dysuria and yellowish discharge. Gram staining shows gram-negative diplococci. What is the diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neisseria

 

The presence of gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain is a classic finding in infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which is a sexually transmitted bacterium responsible for gonorrhea. Neisseria gonorrhoeae typically presents with symptoms such as dysuria (painful urination) and a yellowish or purulent discharge, which aligns with the clinical presentation described in the question.

 

Gram staining is a key diagnostic tool that helps differentiate bacterial species based on the characteristics of their cell walls. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative diplococcus, meaning it appears as paired spherical bacteria that do not retain the crystal violet stain used in gram staining but do take up the counterstain, appearing pink or red under a microscope.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Trichomoniasis: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis, which is a flagellated organism. While trichomoniasis can cause dysuria and yellowish discharge, it would not present with gram-negative diplococci on a gram stain. If the organism had flagella, Trichomoniasis would be a consideration, but the gram stain findings rule it out.

 

Option C. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis is another sexually transmitted bacterium that can cause symptoms similar to those of gonorrhea. However, it does not appear as gram-negative diplococci on gram stain. Instead, it is typically detected by nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT).

 

Option D. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is characterized by an imbalance in the vaginal flora and typically diagnosed using Amsel's criteria or by identifying clue cells on microscopy. It is not associated with gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of gram-negative diplococci in a patient with dysuria and yellowish discharge is highly indicative of Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection, a common cause of gonorrhea

questions.text: A physician observed the following finding in a small child who came for an eye exam. This finding is associated with which of the following conditions?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperopia

 

Esotropia (convergent squint) is commonly seen in children with hyperopia (also known as hypermetropia).

 

Accommodative esotropia:

 

It occurs due to overaction of convergence associated with accommodation reflex. It is of three types:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myopia (Short-sightedness):

  • Esotropia: Less common in myopic children.
  • Refractive Error: Light focuses in front of the retina.
  • Symptoms: Difficulty seeing distant objects clearly.

 

Option B. Astigmatism:

  • Effect on Squint: Can cause both esotropia and exotropia depending on the axis and severity of astigmatism.
  • Refractive Error: Light is focused at multiple points due to an irregular corneal shape.
  • Symptoms: Blurred or distorted vision at all distances.

 

Option D. Emmetropia (Normal Vision):

  • Esotropia: Rarely associated.
  • Refractive Error: No significant refractive error; light focuses correctly on the retina.
  • Symptoms: Normal vision without the need for corrective lenses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperopia is commonly associated with accommodative esotropia in children, where the effort to focus on near objects results in excessive convergence and inward deviation of the eyes. Corrective lenses help to reduce the accommodative effort, thereby alleviating the esotropia.

questions.text: A vegetable vendor with no criminal background, after 1 week is found dead with advanced decomposition. What would you do to recognize the body? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DNA profiling

 

After one week liquefaction occurs, so the body undergoes significant decomposition. General recognition is not helpful due to the gross distortion of the body. Dental records are also not useful because teeth typically fall out within three to five days post-mortem. Fingerprints can be compromised as the skin begins to degrade, with degloving of the skin occurring within three to five days and complete skin decomposition taking up to one month. However, DNA profiling remains a reliable method even in advanced decomposition, as DNA can be extracted from bones and other tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. General recognition: This is ineffective after a week of decomposition due to the significant distortion and liquefaction of the body.

 

Option C. Dental records: Teeth fall out within three to five days after death, making dental records unreliable for identification after one week.

 

Option D. Finger prints: The skin undergoes degloving within three to five days and further decomposition, making fingerprinting unreliable. Additionally, without a criminal background, there would be no pre-existing fingerprint records for comparison.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of advanced decomposition, DNA profiling is the most reliable method for identifying a body, as it can still be obtained from bones and other tissues even after significant decomposition.

questions.text: Which type of graph is used to illustrate studies on healthcare and disease prevalence in a population? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Ishikawa diagram/Fish bone diagram

 

Explanation

 

Ishikawa Diagram/Fish Bone Diagram/ Cause & Effect Diagram:

 

Description: A visual tool that helps trace a problem’s cause back to its roots, creating a branched diagram that looks like a fishbone.

 

Application: Used to identify, explore, and display the possible causes of a particular problem, particularly useful in quality control and prevention strategies in healthcare.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Bar Diagram:

 

Description: Bar diagrams use bars of varying lengths to represent data. Each bar corresponds to a category with a specific quantity.

 

Application: Useful for comparing quantities across different categories, such as the number of cases in different disease categories or patient counts in various demographic groups.

 

Option B. Histogram:

 

Description: A histogram is similar to a bar chart but is used for continuous quantitative data divided into bins or intervals. It helps in understanding the distribution of data.

 

Application: Commonly used to show the distribution of a dataset, such as the age distribution of patients suffering from a specific disease or the distribution of blood pressure readings in a population.

 

Option C. Multiple Regression Model:

 

Description: Not a graph, but a statistical technique that models the relationship between a dependent variable and multiple independent variables.

 

Application: Used to predict outcomes based on several variables, such as predicting patient outcomes based on age, treatment type, and pre-existing conditions.

 

Educational objectives : Fishbone diagrams are instrumental in root cause analysis, helping healthcare teams systematically investigate the contributory factors leading to health issues or outbreaks.

choices.text: Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

questions.text: A patient with CKD with refractory hypertension is brought to the casualty with dizziness. His BP was found to be 200/120 mmHg. His BUN was 50 mg/dl and creatinine was 3 mg/dl. Potassium was 6 mEq/L. Which of the following is an indication of emergency hemodialysis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated in several critical conditions commonly remembered with the mnemonic AEIOU:

 

  1. Acidosis: Severe metabolic acidosis that is not responsive to standard medical therapy, particularly when the pH is less than 7.1.
  2. Electrolyte imbalance: Severe hyperkalemia, especially when potassium levels are more than 6.5 mEq/L, rapidly rising, or refractory to medical management.
  3. Intoxications: With dialyzable drugs.
  4. Overload: Volume overload state, such as diuretic-resistant pulmonary edema, particularly when oxygen requirements are increasing.
  5. Uremia: Uremic complications such as pericarditis or encephalopathy, which are urgent indications due to the risk of tamponade or severe cognitive impairment.

 

In this patient, severe acidosis, alongside elevated BUN and creatinine, is a strong indication for emergency hemodialysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypertension: Hypertension alone, even when severe, is not an immediate indication for emergency hemodialysis

 

Option C. Potassium level of 6 mEq/L: While elevated, a potassium level of 6 mEq/L by itself is not enough to indicate emergency dialysis unless it is rapidly rising or refractory to treatment. Typically, levels above 6.5 mEq/L are considered more critical.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: This is not an indication for emergency hemodialysis. Instead, metabolic acidosis, especially when severe and refractory to treatment, is a more significant concern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency hemodialysis is indicated for severe acidosis, refractory hyperkalemia, volume overload, intoxications, and uremic complications. Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine is a critical indication for initiating emergency hemodialysis.

questions.text: All of the following oncogenic viruses can integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HTLV

 

  • HTLV - Human T cell lymphotropic virus causes microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.
  • Oncoviruses are classified as direct or indirect carcinogens, although some overlap exists between the distinction. Direct carcinogenic viruses possess viral oncogenes that directly contribute to neoplastic cellular transformation, whereas indirect carcinogens cause chronic inflammation, which can lead to oncogenic transformation.
  • DNA tumor viruses encode viral oncoproteins which may become integrated into the host cell chromosome.
  • RNA viruses are known to cause microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV (Human Papillomavirus):

 

  • Mechanism: HPV integrates its DNA into the host genome, leading to the production of oncoproteins E6 and E7, which inactivate tumor suppressor genes p53 and Rb. This disruption of tumor suppressor pathways contributes to the development of cancers such as cervical cancer.
  • Example: Cervical cancer is a well-documented outcome of HPV infection, particularly with high-risk strains like HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: HBV can integrate its DNA into the host genome, contributing to hepatocellular carcinoma. The integration can lead to genomic instability and the insertional activation of oncogenes or inactivation of tumor suppressor genes.
  • Example: Chronic hepatitis B infection is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option D. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: EBV can integrate into the host genome and produce latent proteins that drive cell proliferation and prevent apoptosis. The viral proteins LMP1 and EBNA2 are key players in this process, contributing to the development of various cancers, including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Example: EBV is strongly associated with Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly in endemic areas such as sub-Saharan Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oncogenic DNA and RNA Viruses:

 

  • Oncogenic DNA Viruses:
    • EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus)
    • HBV (Hepatitis B Virus)
    • HPV (Human Papillomavirus)
    • HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8)
    • MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus)
  • Oncogenic RNA Viruses:
    • HCV (Hepatitis C Virus)
    • HTLV-1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus-1)

questions.text: Following are the reasons for thiamine deficiency Except: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Veganism

 

Explanation

 

While vegan diets exclude animal products, thiamine deficiency is not commonly associated with veganism, especially if the diet is well-planned and includes diverse sources of nutrients. Thiamine is found in whole grains, legumes, seeds, and some fortified foods, which are all components of a typical vegan diet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chronic Alcoholic: Chronic alcoholism is a well-known risk factor for thiamine deficiency. Alcohol impairs thiamine absorption and increases its excretion. Furthermore, alcoholics often have poor dietary intake, contributing to a deficiency. Thiamine deficiency in alcoholics can lead to serious conditions such as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option C. Chronic Use of Diuretics: Prolonged use of diuretics, particularly loop diuretics, can lead to increased urinary excretion of thiamine, thus potentially causing or exacerbating a deficiency. This is especially relevant in patients with conditions like heart failure, where diuretics are commonly prescribed.

 

Option D. Bariatric Surgery: Bariatric surgery, especially procedures that involve bypassing parts of the stomach and small intestine, can lead to malabsorption of various nutrients, including thiamine. Patients undergoing bariatric surgery are at risk for nutritional deficiencies and require careful monitoring and supplementation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Major source of Thiamine are whole grains and cereals. So, veganism does not cause thiamine deficiency.
  • Thiamine (also known as vitamin B1) deficiency can be caused by a variety of factors, including:

 

Poor nutrition: Thiamine deficiency is most commonly caused by inadequate dietary intake of thiamine-rich foods such as whole grains, legumes, nuts, and meat.

 

Alcoholism: Chronic alcohol consumption can interfere with the absorption and utilization of thiamine in the body, leading to deficiency.

 

Malabsorption disorders: Conditions such as celiac disease, Crohn's disease, and ulcerative colitis can impair the body's ability to absorb thiamine from food.

 

Bariatric surgery  Certain types of weight loss surgery, such as gastric bypass, can reduce the body's ability to absorb thiamine.

 

Genetic disorders: Rare genetic disorders such as thiamine-responsive megaloblastic anemia and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome can cause thiamine deficiency.

 

Medications: Some medications, such as diuretics and certain types of chemotherapy, can interfere with thiamine absorption and utilization.

 

Pregnancy and breastfeeding: Pregnant and breastfeeding women have increased thiamine requirements and may develop deficiency if their intake is insufficient.

 

Aging: Older adults may be at increased risk of thiamine deficiency due to decreased absorption and utilization of the vitamin.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 541-542

choices.text: Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia
Loss of long-term memory but intact personality
Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall

questions.text: Which of the following is true statement about Korsakoff syndrome? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). The most common cause is alcohol misuse, but other conditions that affect nutrition can also lead to Korsakoff syndrome. Its main feature is anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory i.e., patients with Korsakoff syndrome can't acquire new information or recall recent events, but long-term memories from before the onset of the illness remain intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia: Refers to Wernicke's encephalopathy, which often precedes Korsakoff syndrome and presents with a triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. If left untreated, Wernicke's can progress to Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option B. Loss of long-term memory but intact personality: While long-term memories may be affected in Korsakoff syndrome, it is not a characteristic feature. Personality changes, apathy, and lack of insight can be seen.

 

Option D. Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall: Korsakoff syndrome predominantly affects explicit memory (conscious recall of facts and events), not implicit memory (unconscious memory like skills).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It is primarily associated with chronic alcohol misuse. It is characterized by anterograde amnesia (difficulty forming new memories) and often retrograde amnesia (loss of past memories). Confabulation is common, where patients fill memory gaps with fabricated information. Treatment involves thiamine replacement and abstaining from alcohol. It often follows or coexists with Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is an acute syndrome requiring immediate thiamine treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 38-40.

questions.text: Identify the stapler in the image given below: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Linear stapler

 

The above instrument is a linear stapler.

 

Use: It is used to close the bowel completely or partially.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A linear stapler is used to close the bowel completely or partially, providing a secure and uniform closure in gastrointestinal surgeries.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auricular branch of vagus

 

Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

 

Nerve supply of external auditory canal

 

External Auditory Canal

 

  1. Anterior wall and roof: auriculotemporal (V3).
  2. Posterior wall and floor: auricular branch of vagus (CN X) aka Arnolds nerve
  3. Posterior wall of the auditory canal also receives sensory fibres of CN VII through auricular branch of vagus

 

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): Stimulation of Arnold's nerve in the external auditory canal during wax removal evokes reflex cough.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Auriculotemporal nerve - Provides sensation to the anterior wall and roof of the canal, not typically associated with triggering cough.

 

Option C. Great auricular nerve - Primarily involved in the sensation of the skin around the ear, not the inner canal.

 

Option D. Facial nerve - While it contributes sensory fibers, it is not the primary cause of the cough reflex in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ear-cough reflex is a unique physiological reaction mediated by the auricular branch of the vagus nerve, illustrating the interconnectedness of sensory pathways and autonomic responses in the human body.

questions.text: The base sequence of the strand of DNA used as the template for transcription has the base sequence 5'GATCTAC3'. What is the base sequence of RNA product? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5'GUAGAUC3'

 

Explanation:

 

You're given the template strand of DNA:


5′–GATCTAC–3′

 

But remember:

 

  • Transcription reads the DNA template in the 3′ → 5′ direction
  • So we must first reverse the strand to get its 3′ → 5′ orientation
    3′–CATAGTC–5′

 

Now, perform complementary base pairing to make the RNA strand (synthesized 5′ to 3′):

 

 

So the RNA product is:


5′–GUAGAUC–3′

 

Educational Objective

 

The complementary base pairing rules are:

 

  • Adenine (A) pairs with Uracil (U) in RNA.
  • Thymine (T) pairs with Adenine (A).
  • Cytosine (C) pairs with Guanine (G).
  • Guanine (G) pairs with Cytosine (C).

 

The RNA product formed during transcription is complementary to the DNA template strand and follows the base-pairing rules with uracil replacing thymine.

questions.text: Which of the following, when consumed with oral iron, reduces its absorption?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tea

 

Explanation

 

The absorption of oral iron can be affected by various dietary substances. Tea contains tannins, which are polyphenolic compounds that can bind to iron and reduce its absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. This is why tea consumption is often advised to be separated from iron supplementation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Lemon juice: Contains high amounts of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), which actually enhances iron absorption by reducing ferric iron to the more absorbable ferrous form.

 

Option B. Amla juice: Like lemon juice, it is rich in vitamin C and thus enhances iron absorption.

 

Option C. Sprouts: Contain iron and proteins, which can aid in iron absorption.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Tea, due to its tannin content, can reduce the absorption of oral iron when consumed together.

choices.text: Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is false and reason is also true
Assertion is true and reason is also false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Myocarditis is the common known complication of faucial diphtheria


Reason (R) : It is due to bacteremia by diphtheria    (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Assertion is true and reason is also false

 

Explanation:

 

Assertion: Myocarditis is indeed a common and serious complication of diphtheria, especially in cases of faucial diphtheria. The diphtheria toxin can cause significant damage to the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis.

 

Reason: The assertion that myocarditis is due to bacteremia by diphtheria is incorrect. Diphtheria does not cause bacteremia. Instead, the complications, including myocarditis, are due to the exotoxin produced by the Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The toxin disseminates through the bloodstream, affecting various organs, including the heart, nerves, and kidneys.

 

  1. Diphtheria Toxin: The pathogenesis of diphtheria involves the production of diphtheria toxin, which is a potent exotoxin. This toxin, rather than the bacteria itself, enters the bloodstream (toxemia) and affects distant organs.
  2. Toxemia vs. Bacteremia: Diphtheria is characterized by toxemia, not bacteremia. The bacteria remain localized at the site of infection (e.g., the throat), but the toxin spreads systemically.
  3. Myocarditis as a Complication: The diphtheria toxin affects the heart muscle, leading to myocarditis, which is the most common and severe complication of diphtheria. Other complications include neuritis and damage to the adrenal glands.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason given is not the correct explanation.

 

Option B. Assertion is true, reason is true; reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: Incorrect because the reason itself is false.

 

Option C. Assertion is false and reason is also true: Incorrect because the assertion is true, but the reason is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myocarditis is a common and serious complication of diphtheria due to the effects of the diphtheria toxin. It is important to recognize that the complications arise from toxemia, not bacteremia.

questions.text: A female patient presents with severe restlessness, palpitations, and tremors to the emergency department. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, the neck looks swollen. Blood pressure is elevated, and tachycardia is noted. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Which of the following drugs is used for immediate management in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Diltiazem

 

In a patient with atrial fibrillation and bronchial asthma, the primary goal is to control the heart rate. For rate control in atrial fibrillation, beta-blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (NDCCBs) like diltiazem or verapamil are commonly used. However, in this case, the patient has bronchial asthma, which makes the use of beta-blockers (such as propranolol and esmolol) less suitable due to their potential to exacerbate asthma symptoms.

 

Diltiazem is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker that effectively controls the heart rate without affecting bronchial muscle tone, making it a safer option for patients with asthma. Therefore, diltiazem is the drug of choice for immediate management in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker, which can exacerbate bronchial asthma by causing bronchoconstriction. Thus, it is not a suitable choice for patients with asthma.

 

Option C. Esmolol: Similar to propranolol, esmolol is a beta-blocker and can worsen asthma symptoms due to its bronchoconstrictive effects, making it unsuitable for this patient.

 

Option D. Propylthiouracil: This medication is used in the management of thyroid storm, a condition associated with severe hyperthyroidism. It is not relevant for rate control in atrial fibrillation and does not address the immediate needs of this patient's condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For immediate rate control in atrial fibrillation in a patient with bronchial asthma, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like diltiazem are preferred over beta-blockers to avoid exacerbating asthma symptoms.

questions.text: Identify the implant shown in the image used for treatment of proximal femoral fracture. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dynamic hip screw

 

The image shows an implant used for the treatment of proximal femoral fractures, specifically intertrochanteric fractures. The implant depicted is a Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS), which is composed of two main components: a large screw (commonly referred to as a Richard screw) and a plate with a barrel. The screw slides within the barrel as the bone heals, allowing controlled movement and promoting bone union.

 

The DHS has been the gold standard for treating intertrochanteric fractures, especially extracapsular femoral neck fractures. It works by providing stability while allowing dynamic compression at the fracture site, which helps in bone healing. However, with advancements in medical technology, cephalomedullary nails (such as the proximal femoral nail) have largely replaced the DHS for such fractures in recent times.

 

Two types of proximal femoral fractures:

 

  1. Fracture of the neck of femur (intra-capsular):
    • Less than 65 years of age: Perform closed reduction (do not open) and fix with cannulated cancellous screw fixation (fixation with screws).
    • More than or equal to 65 years of age: Perform hemiarthroplasty (replace half the joint).
    • Any age with joint damage: Perform total hip replacement (for hip joint damage).
    • Neck of femur fracture is also referred to as the unsolved fracture.
  2. Intertrochanteric fractures:
    • Treatment options include the dynamic hip screw or proximal femoral fracture treatment.
    • Modern treatment involves placing nails:
      • Cephalomedullary or proximal femoral nail: A nail is placed inside the femur, with a screw into the head of the femur.
    • Fractures lower down: Treated with interlock nailing.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dynamic condylar plate: The dynamic condylar plate is primarily used for distal femoral fractures, not proximal femoral fractures like intertrochanteric fractures. It does not have the screw-barrel mechanism that is specific to the dynamic hip screw.

 

Option C. Dynamic trochanteric plate: While similar-sounding, the dynamic trochanteric plate is not commonly used for intertrochanteric fractures. The DHS is more specifically designed for dynamic compression in such cases.

 

Option D. Limited contact condylar plate: This plate is generally used for fractures that require minimal disturbance of the periosteum, but it is not typically used for intertrochanteric fractures, which require dynamic fixation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS) is a two-part implant, featuring a screw and a plate, and is used to treat intertrochanteric fractures of the proximal femur.

choices.text: Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to right sensory cortex
Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to left sensory cortex

questions.text: After a right limb amputation, the patient is experiencing severe pain (phantom limb). What is the mechanism behind this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to left sensory cortex

 

When a limb is amputated, the sensory input from that limb is lost. However, the brain's sensory cortex, which was originally responsible for receiving input from that limb, does not remain idle. Due to the phenomenon known as cortical plasticity, the brain adapts by allowing adjacent areas of the sensory cortex to project their fibers into the area that previously received input from the amputated limb.

 

Since sensory information from the right limb is processed in the contralateral (left) sensory cortex, it is the left sensory cortex that experiences changes. The adjacent fibers from neighboring cortical areas begin to overlap and take over the area previously occupied by the input from the now-amputated right limb. This can lead to the sensation of phantom pain, where the patient feels pain in the missing limb as the brain "misinterprets" signals from these newly connected areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Projection of adjacent fibers to overlap to right sensory cortex: This is incorrect because sensory input from the right limb is processed in the left sensory cortex, not the right. Therefore, changes due to cortical plasticity would occur in the left cortex, not the right.

 

Option C. Expansion of right sensory cortex: The concept of cortical expansion does not apply here. In cases of amputation, the cortex area corresponding to the amputated limb doesn't expand but rather is taken over by adjacent cortical areas. Also, any changes would occur in the left cortex, not the right.

 

Option D. Expansion of left sensory cortex: While the left sensory cortex is indeed involved, the term "expansion" is not accurate in this context. It is the overlapping projection of adjacent fibers that occurs, not an expansion of the cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cortical plasticity allows adjacent cortical areas to project into regions that have lost their original sensory input, such as after limb amputation. This often leads to phantom limb pain, where the sensation of the missing limb is still perceived.

questions.text:
Which of the following statement/s is/are true regarding open fracture?(INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Compartment syndrome is rare.
  2. Immediate debridement should be done.
  3. Tibia is the most common long bone involved.
  4. Multiple fractures are uncommon.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) I, II & III are correct

 

I. Compartment syndrome is rare: True

 

  • In open fractures, the fascia may be disrupted, which reduces the risk of rising compartment pressure.

  • However, compartment syndrome can still occur, especially in high-energy injuries, so it is not impossible, but it is less common compared to closed fractures.

 

II. Immediate debridement should be done: True

 

  • Early and thorough surgical debridement is the cornerstone of open fracture management to reduce infection risk.

  • Ideally performed within 6–8 hours, though recent evidence suggests that a short delay may not significantly change infection rates if antibiotics are given promptly.

 

III. Tibia is the most common long bone involved: True

 

  • The tibia is the most commonly involved long bone in open fractures due to its subcutaneous location (minimal soft tissue coverage).

  • Therefore, it’s more vulnerable to open injuries, especially in road traffic accidents.

 

IV. Multiple fractures are uncommon: False

  • Multiple fractures are actually common, particularly in high-energy trauma like road traffic accidents, falls from height, or blast injuries.

  • Open fractures often occur as part of polytrauma.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In open fracture, compartment syndrome is a rare entity as the fracture communicates with the surrounding atmosphere, preventing an increase in the compartment pressure.
  • These fractures need immediate irrigation with antibiotics and debridement of the wound.
  • Tibia is the most common site for open fractures after phalanges.

questions.text: In methanol poisoning, which of these is increased in the blood? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Formic acid and lactic acid


Methanol poisoning occurs when methanol is metabolized in the body. Methanol is first converted to formaldehyde, which is then further metabolized to formic acid. Formic acid is toxic and interferes with cellular respiration, inhibiting the normal production of ATP. This interference pushes the body towards anaerobic metabolism, leading to the accumulation of lactic acid in the blood. Therefore, in methanol poisoning, both formic acid and lactic acid levels are elevated due to disrupted cellular respiration and subsequent anaerobic metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formic acid and glycolic acid: Glycolic acid is primarily associated with ethylene glycol poisoning, not methanol poisoning. In methanol poisoning, formic acid is the primary metabolite responsible for toxicity.

 

Option B. Oxalic and formic acid: Oxalic acid is a major toxic metabolite of ethylene glycol, not methanol. In methanol poisoning, formic acid is the main toxic substance, and oxalic acid does not play a role.

 

Option C. Glycolic and lactic acid: Glycolic acid is related to ethylene glycol poisoning, not methanol poisoning. While lactic acid can be elevated due to anaerobic metabolism, glycolic acid is not a product of methanol metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:


In methanol poisoning, formic acid and lactic acid levels increase due to disrupted cellular respiration and anaerobic metabolism.

questions.text: In a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following lipid would be deficient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline

 

This is the correct answer. DPPC is a major component of pulmonary surfactant, and its deficiency in preterm infants is a key factor in the development of RDS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is not the deficient lipid in RDS. While it is a component of pulmonary surfactant, the primary deficiency in RDS is of DPPC.

 

L:S (Lecithin: Sphingomyelin) ratio > 2 is an indicator of fetal lung maturity at 32 weeks of gestation.

 

Option B. Cardiolipin: Cardiolipin is not the deficient lipid in RDS. It is found in the inner mitochondrial membrane and is not directly related to pulmonary surfactant.

 

Disease related to Cardiolipins

 

  1. Barth Syndrome: Defect in cardiolipin remodelling
  2. Anti-Phospholipid Syndrome: Occurs due to Anticardiolipin antibodies formed in body. C/f are A thrombotic condition and Disease females has history of recurrent infection

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because, as explained above, DPPC is deficient in preterm babies with RDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDS occurs when there is not enough surfactant in the lungs. Surfactant is a liquid made by the lungs that keeps the airways (alveoli) open. Pulmonary surfactant is a surface-active lipoprotein complex (phospholipoprotein) formed by type II alveolar cells. The proteins and lipids that make up the surfactant have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions. By adsorbing to the air-water interface of alveoli, with hydrophilic head groups in the water and the hydrophobic tails facing towards the air, the main lipid component of surfactant is dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC).

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 234

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a history of repeated sinopulmonary infections caused by encapsulated organisms. Which of the following is most likely to be deficient in this case? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgG2

 

IgG2 deficiency is the most likely culprit in cases where a child suffers from recurrent sinopulmonary infections specifically caused by encapsulated bacteria. IgG2 plays a critical role in the immune system's ability to fight off encapsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria meningitidis. These organisms are particularly adept at evading non-specific immune responses due to their polysaccharide capsules, making specific antibody-mediated immunity crucial.

 

Transplacental Transport of IgG: IgG is unique among the immunoglobulins as it is transported from mother to fetus across the placenta, providing passive immunity to the newborn. IgG1 is transported most efficiently across the placenta, providing early defense against infection in neonates. IgG2, despite being critical for defense against encapsulated bacteria, has less transplacental movement, which can influence the susceptibility to infections in early infancy before the infant's own immune system fully matures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgG1: Predominantly responsible for protecting against bacterial infections, including pathogens like diphtheria and tetanus.

 

Option C. IgG3: Often associated with a stronger response to viral infections.

 

Option D. IgG4: Less common and typically related to responses against parasitic infections, though IgG4-related disease can also manifest as fibroinflammatory conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children presenting with recurrent infections caused by encapsulated bacteria, IgG2 deficiency should be considered as a possible underlying cause. Early identification and management of specific immunoglobulin deficiencies are crucial to prevent recurrent infections and their complications in young children.

questions.text: Which of the following steps is not included in WHO's STEP approach?[NEET  PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Therapeutic assessment

 

  • STEPwise approach to surveillance (STEPS) is a simple, standardized method by WHO for surveillance. It is of two types:
    • STEPwise approach to chronic disease risk factor surveillance
    • STEPwise approach to Stroke surveillance

questions.text: Cutis marmorata occurs due to? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Exposure to cold temperature

 

  • Cutis marmorata, also known as physiological livedo reticularis, describes the pinkish-blue mottled or marbled appearance of the skin that occurs when exposed to cold temperatures.

 

Fig: Cutis marmorata

 

  • During infancy, about half of all children exhibit a noticeable marbling pattern on their skin when exposed to cooler temperatures.
  • This effect arises from the simultaneous dilation and contraction of the superficial capillaries and may continue throughout early childhood.
  • However, the skin returns to its regular appearance when warmed again, indicating that this is a natural physiological response and does not necessitate any intervention.
  • Nevertheless, persistent cutis marmorata may be observed in individuals with trisomies 18 and 21.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exposure to hot temperature

 

 

Erythema Ab Igne over thigh

 

 

Option B. An adverse reaction to drugs: They can cause various skin manifestations, including rashes, urticaria, or specific reactions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome, but not cutis marmorata.

 

Option D. Humidity: It is not known to cause cutis marmorata. High humidity can lead to other skin issues like sweating and chafing, but it does not cause the vascular changes seen in cutis marmorata.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutis marmorata is a skin condition characterized by a marbled appearance of the skin, resulting from exposure to cold temperatures due to the vascular response of constriction and dilation.

 

References

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Chapter 25, Page no 125.7

 

Question Level – Intermediate

Question Id-7447 Unique Key-Q6575185

questions.text: A 32-year-old female in late pregnancy presents with seizures and high-grade blood pressure. She is diagnosed with eclampsia and started on magnesium sulfate therapy. As part of her management, certain parameters require close monitoring to prevent magnesium toxicity. Which of the following parameters does not require routine checking during magnesium sulfate therapy in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum magnesium levels

 

Magnesium sulfate is used in the management of eclampsia to prevent and control seizures. However, because magnesium can be toxic at high levels, close monitoring of certain clinical parameters (urine output, deep tendon reflexes and respiratory rate) is essential to avoid complications.

 

Serum magnesium levels, on the other hand, do not require routine monitoring unless there is a clinical suspicion of toxicity based on the above parameters. Routine monitoring of serum magnesium levels is not typically done unless symptoms suggest toxicity, making it the correct answer to this question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urine output: Essential for monitoring kidney function and preventing magnesium accumulation. Urine output needs to be monitored because decreased kidney function can lead to magnesium accumulation and toxicity. If urine output is less than 25-30 ml/hour (or 100 ml over 4 hours), magnesium sulfate should be withheld.

 

Option B. Deep tendon reflexes: Critical for early detection of magnesium toxicity. A decrease or absence of reflexes indicates that magnesium levels may be too high.

 

Option D. Respiratory rate: Vital for detecting severe toxicity and preventing respiratory arrest. If the respiratory rate drops below 12 breaths per minute, it suggests that magnesium levels are dangerously high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While managing eclampsia with magnesium sulfate, routine monitoring of deep tendon reflexes, urine output, and respiratory rate is crucial. Serum magnesium levels are only checked if toxicity is suspected, not as a routine measure.

questions.text: The following scan is of a young woman on oral contraceptives. The most likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hepatic adenoma

 

The image given is of hepatic adenoma which is the most frequent hepatic tumor in young women on oral contraceptive pills. Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors, predisposed in patients on OCPs and glycogen storage disorders with a predilection for hemorrhage. They are enhancing lesions on the arterial phase.

 

  • Liver tumors - IOC: Triple phase CT
  • Typical appearance of hemangioma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma: More commonly associated with chronic liver disease and hepatitis B or C infections.

 

Option B. Metastatic infiltrates: Typically appear as multiple lesions with variable enhancement patterns depending on the primary cancer's nature.

 

Option D. Hemangioma: The most common benign liver tumor, characterized by its classic "light bulb" bright enhancement on T2-weighted MRI images, not typically associated with oral contraceptive use.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic adenomas are benign liver tumors often associated with the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs). They occur more frequently in young women and are known for their risk of hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which hormone increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GH

 

Growth Hormone (GH) is unique in that it increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep. GH plays a crucial role in growth, metabolism, and overall bodily repair and regeneration. During deep sleep, especially during slow-wave sleep, GH secretion peaks. This is vital for tissue growth and repair.

 

Stress and starvation also trigger the release of GH, which helps in mobilizing fat stores for energy and preserving muscle mass, among other functions. These adaptive responses are crucial for survival during periods of physical or emotional stress and food scarcity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucocorticoids:  These hormones, which include cortisol, increase in response to stress and starvation. However, their levels typically decrease during deep sleep and peak in the early morning hours.

 

Option C. Cortisol:  A specific glucocorticoid that increases in response to stress and starvation, but like other glucocorticoids, its levels decrease during deep sleep and peak early in the morning.

 

Option D. Prolactin:  This hormone can increase in response to stress and has a role in metabolism and immune regulation, but it does not have the same peak during deep sleep as GH does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth Hormone (GH) is the hormone that increases during periods of stress, starvation, and especially deep sleep, distinguishing it from other hormones that typically decrease during deep sleep.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis is not responding well to conventional treatment. Her rheumatologist is considering adding tocilizumab to her treatment regimen. Which of the following interleukins (IL) is primarily targeted by tocilizumab? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IL-6

 

  • Tocilizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets and inhibits the interleukin-6 (IL-6) receptor. By blocking the IL-6 receptor, tocilizumab interrupts the signaling pathway of IL-6, a cytokine involved in the inflammatory response. This is particularly beneficial in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, where elevated levels of IL-6 contribute to the inflammatory process.
  • Tocilizumab has also been used in COVID-19 for cytokine release syndrome.
  • It is avoided in patients with liver disease, immunosuppression, having a high risk of GIT perforation, Absolute Neutrophil Count <500 cell/µl and Platelet count <50000 cells/µl.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IL-2: Drugs like basiliximab or daclizumab are used to target IL-2 receptors.

 

Option C. IL-4: Dupilumab is an example of a medication that targets IL-4.

 

Option D. IL-5: Mepolizumab and reslizumab are examples of medications that target IL-5.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tocilizumab targets the IL-6 receptor, making it effective for managing rheumatoid arthritis and certain other inflammatory conditions by inhibiting the IL-6 signaling pathway.

questions.text: Implantation of the fertilized ovum typically occurs on which day post-fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Day 5

 

Explanation:

 

Implantation typically occurs between the 6th to 10th day post-fertilization. According to embryological references such as Langevin and Larson, implantation generally begins around the 5th to 6th day. However, in this specific question, since Day 6 is not listed among the options, the best available choice is Day 5, which aligns closely with the actual timing of implantation onset.

 

During early embryogenesis, the blastocyst stage, which is the stage right before implantation, is typically reached around Day 5. At this point, the blastocyst is ready to implant into the uterine wall, initiating the process of establishing pregnancy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Implantation typically begins around the 5th to 6th day after fertilization, with Day 5 often representing the initial attachment of the blastocyst to the uterine lining. If Day 6 is not an option, choose the next closest day, which is Day 5.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the given X-ray finding seen? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Reflux esophagitis

 

The given image is a barium swallow X-ray showing a feline esophagus suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis seen in asthma and GERD.

 

Other important barium swallow signs:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophageal atresia: This condition involves a discontinuity of the esophagus and is typically diagnosed in neonates.

 

Option B. Esophageal stenosis: Esophageal stenosis would show as a narrowing of the esophagus on an X-ray, which is not evident in the provided image.

 

Option D. Barrett's esophagus: Barrett's esophagus involves a change in the esophageal lining from squamous to columnar epithelium due to chronic acid exposure. While it may be associated with GERD, its specific changes are not visible on a barium swallow X-ray and are instead diagnosed through endoscopic biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appearance of a feline esophagus on a barium swallow X-ray is indicative of eosinophilic esophagitis and is often associated with conditions like asthma and GERD. This finding underscores the importance of considering inflammatory and allergic contributions in patients presenting with esophageal symptoms.

questions.text: A patient was brought to casualty with seizures. He had multiple episodes and was taking herbal medicines for the same. He was conscious in between the episodes. During the episodes, he had arching of his back. What is the likely cause? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Strychnine

 

STRYCHNINE NUX VOMICA

 

Active Principle: Strychnine, Brucine

 

Most Toxic part: Seeds (Fatal dose: 1 crushed seed; uncrushed seed not toxic)

 

MOA –

 

  • Competitive antagonist of glycine at post synaptic receptors
  • Strychnine inhibits the uptake of glycine, which is an inhibitory neurotransmitter at post-synaptic junction which gives excitatory effects
  • Spinal Cord: Anterior horn cells & brain stem also.

 

Clinical Presentation –

 

  • Very sudden onset
  • Dramatic presentation
  • “Conscious seizures”
    • Generalized
    • Simultaneous Convulsions (2-3 mins): All muscles affected at once
    • In b/w contractions muscles completely relaxed (5 mins)
      • Death occurs after 5-6 convulsions (1-2 hrs)

 

1. Opisthotonos: Hyper extension of spine

 

2. Emprosthotonus: Forward bending of spine (Sometimes)

 

3. Pleurosthotonus: Sideways bending of spine (Sometimes)

 

4. Risus Sardonicus: Contraction of facial muscles leading to smiling face

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Ricinus communis (Castor) poisoning leads to burning pain in throat, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea and death.

 

Option C: Nerium odorum (cardiac poison) causes headache, dizziness, vomiting, low blood pressure, fibrillation, AV block, coma, and death can occur due to cardiac failure.

 

Option D: Datura poisoning show symptoms like

 

  • Dry hot skin
  • Dilatation of pupils
  • Diplopia
  • Dry mouth
  • Dysphagia
  • Dysarthria
  • Drunken gait
  • Delirium
  • Drowsiness
  • Death due to respiratory or cardiac failure

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strychnine poisoning presents with characteristic "conscious seizures" and back arching (opisthotonos) due to its antagonistic action on glycine receptors.

choices.text: Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents in OPD with complaints of cyclical pain in abdomen.  On examination, a suprapubic bulge can be seen in the pelvic area. PR examination reveals a swelling in the anterior aspect. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

 

Explanation:

 

The given case scenario points to a diagnosis of cryptomenorrhea, due to an imperforate hymen.

 

Cryptomenorrhea is a condition in which menstruation occurs but is not visible due to obstruction of the outflow tract resulting in either hematometra (blood collection within the uterus) or hematocolpos (blood collection within vagina). In the long term, it may result in endometriosis, urinary retention and infertility.

 

IMPERFORATE HYMEN

 

  • Presents as cryptomenorrhea
  • H/o cyclical abdominal pain/cyclical dysmenorrhea
  • Local examination: bluish bulge with intact hymen
  • On P/R: swelling (hematocolpos) felt along length of vagina anteriorly
  • Treatment: Cruciate incision.

 

 

In Imperforate hymen, swelling is seen all along the length of the vagina on PR examination as there is hematocolpos (blood in the vagina)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transverse vaginal septum: Transverse vaginal septum is a Müllerian anomaly. On examination, blind vagina is found. No tense blue hymen and cough impulse will be absent. Diagnosis can be confirmed by MRI

 

Option B. Vaginal atresia: If vaginal introitus is not seen, then it’s vaginal atresia

 

Option D. Cervical agenesis: Cervical agenesis will show absence of a cervix is on examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imperforate hymen presents with cryptomenorrhea, characterized by cyclical abdominal pain and hematocolpos due to obstruction of menstrual flow, with a suprapubic bulge and anterior swelling palpable on PR examination.

questions.text: The given image shows what grade of placenta previa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) III

 

Explanation:

 

The image illustrates Type 3 placenta previa where the placenta partially covers the internal os. This classification is part of the older classification system known as Browne’s classification.

 

Placenta previa is categorized into different types based on how much the placenta covers the internal os of the cervix:

 

Older Classification (Browne’s classification):

 

  • Type 1: The lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment but is away from the os.
  • Type 2: The placenta reaches the margin of the os but doesn’t cover it.
  • Type 3: The placenta partially covers the internal os (when fully dilated, it doesn’t cover).
  • Type 4: The placenta completely covers the os.

 

Newer Classification (based on Transvaginal Sonography - TVS; by ACOG):

 

  1. True Placenta Previa: The placenta covers the internal os.
  2. Low-lying Placenta: The placenta lies within 2 cm of the internal os but does not cover it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV: This would mean the placenta completely covers the os, which is not the case in the given image.

 

Option C. II: This would mean the placenta reaches the margin of the os but does not cover it, which is not consistent with the image.

 

Option D. I: This would mean the lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment but is away from the os, which does not align with the given image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Placenta previa is classified based on the extent to which the placenta covers the internal os, with Type 3 indicating partial coverage.

 

Types of Placentae previa

 

Older Classification (Browne’s classification)

 

 

 

Newer Classification (based on Transvaginal Sonography -TVS); By ACOG

 

  1. True Placenta Previa: Placenta covers the internal os
  2. Low lying placenta: Placenta lies within 2 cm of the internal os but does not cover it. 

 

Ref: Page 658, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text:
During the discharge of a COVID patient who was treated with steroids and remdesivir, which of the following will you inform him about? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

 

  1. Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge
  2. Watch for the persistence of Anosmia
  3. Watch for Headache and nasal discharge
  4. Monitor glucose levels
  5. Watch for Sinusitis-like symptoms
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4 and 5

 

Discharging a COVID-19 patient involves providing instructions for monitoring ongoing or potential symptoms and managing side effects of treatments such as steroids and remdesivir.

 

3. Watch for headache and nasal discharge: These symptoms can be part of the post-COVID syndrome or could indicate secondary infections like sinusitis, especially after treatment that might suppress the immune system.

 

4. Monitor glucose levels: Steroids, often used in the treatment of severe COVID-19, can elevate blood glucose levels. It’s crucial for patients, especially those with pre-existing diabetes or those who experienced high glucose levels during treatment, to monitor their levels after discharge.

 

5. Watch for sinusitis-like symptoms: As with headache and nasal discharge, symptoms like those of sinusitis might suggest secondary infections, which are important to monitor given the use of immunomodulating treatments like steroids.

 

Other Options:
 

1. Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge: Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge is not required as per updated guidelines. Repeat RT-PCR at 7 days of discharge was initially suggested, but later on removed from the guideline. 
 

2. Watch for the persistence of Anosmia: Watch for the persistence of Anosmia is a common symptom (Anosmia can persist for weeks together) but, not matching with the options (actual answer should be 2,3,4, and 5).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients recovering from COVID-19 should monitor for symptoms of headache and nasal discharge, glucose levels due to steroid use, and sinusitis-like symptoms which could indicate secondary infections like mucormycosis.

questions.text: Cytotoxic and expired medications are appropriately discarded through: [NEET PG 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Incineration

 

  • Expired and cytotoxic drugs should be disposed of using specific methods, such as incineration, encapsulation, or plasma pyrolysis, and should be returned to the manufacturer if possible.
  • Other medications can also be disposed of using similar methods.
  • The use of yellow bags is common for hazardous waste to ensure proper handling and disposal by trained personnel.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Do UPT and then give DMPA

questions.text: A female patient taking DMPA came 14 days late. What should be advised to her? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give DMPA, no backup required

 

When a patient is up to 15 days late for a Depo-Provera (DMPA) injection, it is generally safe to administer the injection without additional contraceptive backup.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do UPT and then give DMPA: Pregnancy testing is typically not required unless the delay exceeds 15 days.

 

Option B. DMPA + 7 days backup: Backup contraception is recommended if the delay exceeds 15 days.

 

Option C. DMPA from next cycle: There is no need to wait until the next cycle if the delay is within 15 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients receiving DMPA who are less than 15 days late for their injection, it can be administered without the need for additional contraceptive measures or delay.

questions.text: Which contrast agent is safe in a patient with renal failure? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) USG contrast agents

 

Ultrasound (USG) contrast agents, specifically SONO (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles), are safe to use in patients with renal failure. These microbubbles are filled with gas and are excreted via the lungs rather than the kidneys, making them suitable for patients with compromised renal function. Unlike other contrast agents, USG contrast agents do not rely on renal clearance, thereby avoiding the risk of further renal damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI contrast agents (Gadolinium-based): These agents are contraindicated in renal failure due to the risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, a serious condition affecting the skin and internal organs.

 

Option C. Iodinated contrast: Commonly used in CT imaging, these agents are contraindicated in renal failure due to the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy, which can further impair renal function.

 

Option D. CT contrast agent: Typically, iodinated contrast is used in CT imaging, which is not safe for patients with renal failure for the reasons mentioned above.

 

Educational Objective:

 

USG contrast agents, such as SONO (sulfur hexafluoride microbubbles), are the only contrast agents safe for use in patients with renal failure as they are excreted via the lungs and do not rely on renal clearance.

questions.text: Which muscle is attached to the marked bony structure? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iliopsoas

 

Explanation:

 

The radiograph shows a lateral view of the pelvis and proximal femur. The marked bony structure is the lesser trochanter of the femur. The iliopsoas muscle, consisting of the iliacus and psoas major muscles, attaches to the lesser trochanter.

 

The iliopsoas crosses the hip joint anteriorly, causing flexion. The iliacus originates from the iliac fossa, while the psoas major originates from the lumbar vertebrae. These two muscles fuse together and insert near the lesser trochanter of the femur, forming the floor of the femoral triangle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gluteus maximus : The gluteus maximus muscle inserts on the gluteal tuberosity of the femur, not the lesser trochanter.

 

Option C. Gluteus medius : The gluteus medius muscle inserts on the greater trochanter of the femur, not the lesser trochanter.

 

Option D. Sartorius : The sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle but does not attach directly to the lesser trochanter. It inserts on the medial surface of the proximal tibia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The iliopsoas muscle, consisting of the iliacus and psoas major, inserts on the lesser trochanter of the femur. It is an important hip flexor muscle.

 

Femoral Triangle:

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with right-sided serous otitis media and history of cervical lymphadenopathy. The probable diagnosis is:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nasopharyngeal cancer

 

Given the age of the patient and the presence of both right-sided serous otitis media and cervical lymphadenopathy, the most likely diagnosis is Nasopharyngeal cancer.

 

Nasopharyngeal cancer can present with serous otitis media due to Eustachian tube obstruction by the tumor or swollen lymph nodes in the nasopharyngeal region. Cervical lymphadenopathy is also a common finding due to the spread of the malignancy to the lymph nodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Angiofibroma, specifically juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, is a benign tumor that predominantly affects adolescent males. It can cause nasal obstruction and epistaxis (nosebleeds), but is less commonly associated with serous otitis media and is not typically diagnosed in a 50-year-old male.

 

Option C. Adenoid hypertrophy is more common in children and can cause eustachian tube dysfunction leading to serous otitis media; however, it is unlikely to be associated with cervical lymphadenopathy, especially in adults.

 

Option D. Otitis media with effusion, also known as serous otitis media, is the accumulation of fluid within the middle ear without signs of acute infection. It can be a result of eustachian tube dysfunction, which could be secondary to a mass effect from a nasopharyngeal tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When an adult patient presents with serous otitis media and cervical lymphadenopathy, it is crucial to consider nasopharyngeal cancer as a possible diagnosis, especially in the context of risk factors such as age over 50 years and a history suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text: An elderly woman underwent surgical resection of her bowel, and after a few months, she presents with easy fatiguability and tiredness. Blood smear evaluation shows macrocytic anemia. Which of the following bowel resections is least likely to cause this condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenum

 

The clinical scenario indicates a diagnosis of macrocytic anemia due to vitamin B12 and/or folate deficiency. The resection of the duodenum is least likely to cause this condition. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum, and intrinsic factor (IF) secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach is necessary for its absorption. Vitamin B12 is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia with a peripheral smear showing macro-ovalocytes and a hypersegmented neutrophil. In contrast, the jejunum is mainly used in folic acid absorption, and the stomach and ileum are involved in the absorption of vitamin B12.

 

While the duodenum contributes to overall nutrient absorption, vitamin B12 absorption is mainly absorbed in the ileum. So, resection of the duodenum alone might not as severely impact vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Resection of the jejunum can potentially lead to malabsorption of folic acid, as this is primarily absorbed in the jejunum or ileum.

 

Option C. Ileum: The ileum is a significant site for the absorption of vitamin B12 and is also involved in folic acid absorption. Resection of the ileum can severely disrupt the absorption of these nutrients, leading to macrocytic anemia.

 

Option D. Stomach: The stomach is the site for production of intrinsic factor, required for B12 absorption.
